title.rendered: The Most Common Job Interview Questions: How to Answer Them!

content.rendered:
Interview question: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

Answer: I see myself as a sincere, hardworking professional of society in the coming years.
Me, in my head: (Sipping on margaritas, on an island far, far away.)

Q: Why do you want to work for us?

A: You’re revolutionizing the industry, and I would love to learn from your work and help you with your mission.
Me, in my head: (I’m broke and I need to get paid)

Q: Out of all the candidates, why should we hire you?

A: Because I’m a team player. I’m a hardworking and self-motivated individual.
Me, in my head: (I REPEAT, I AM MORE BROKE THAN YOUR OTHER CANDIDATES, AND I NEED MONEY!)

Feels familiar?

Now that many of us are be sitting at home, trying to ace the next job interview online, we need to have the answers prepared. Maybe in the real world, you could have expressed more with your body language (your aura and friendliness, your perfect smile, hypnosis, etc.). But in the virtual world, your words matter more than ever.

So read on and get ahead by preparing the answers to the most common job interview questions:

Common interview question 1: So, tell me a little about yourself!

It always sounds so simple, but when asked at an interview, you always find yourself sitting there with the word ‘Umm’ coming out of your mouth like a newborn.

Although some uses are natural, you need to avoid overusing the ‘umm’ followed by the recitation of your resume; make yourself look like the professional you are.

The first step is to do your research on the company. Then think about the parts of your experience that could prove to be relevant.

Talk about how you reached your current work position and company, your ambitions when you were in college, and whether they are different now. This is a very common interview question where they seek to hear about your personal life experiences or reasons for gaps in your resume.

Question 2: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

Talk about your long-term goals with the company, what you intend to do while you work for the position offered to you, and how it will be relevant to your future goals. Moreover, be sincere and honest during the interview. If lying on the beach is where you see yourself in 5 years, tell them it would be on a business trip as a reward for the excellent job you would do!

Question 3: Why are you leaving your current job?

First things first: If you were let go, it’s completely OKAY to admit it (especially now, with COVID-19 disrupting job sectors). Mention what didn’t work out and how you’ve been working hard to improve.

But if you’re leaving your current job, DO NOT shine a negative light on your job, employer, or colleagues. The interviewer is not your colleague or friend. Instead, you could say things like: your ideas and goals do not match with your current company/employer/projects. Don’t miss the opportunity during a job interview to talk about how you wish to explore new skills and opportunities to develop a more versatile portfolio.

Are you waiting to hear back after an interview? Here’s what you can do in the meantime!

Question 4: Why should we hire you?

Remember that an interview is always a two-way street. So, list down your positive attributes that would benefit your employer. Then tell them about how YOU would benefit from the position.

Question 5: What are your strengths and weaknesses?

To tackle this trick question, frame your answer in a way that does not oversell or undersell your qualities as an employee.

Think of a quality that you honestly consider to be your weakness and add how you’re working to improve the said weakness.

Similarly, when it comes to your strengths, do not try to oversell. Think of something that caters to the needs of the position. Also, support your answers to tricky job interview questions with relevant and brief examples.

Related: How To Turn Any Job Into Your Dream Job

Question 6: Do you have any questions for me?

This is an opportunity for you to investigate. Don’t let it go. Moreover, this is a common interview question they expect an answer for although it may seem otherwise!

No matter how badly you want a job, you need to protect yourself from toxic work environments, abusive employers, and work hours. So make a good list of things you would like to know and ask the most important ones. Some of them could be about their work hours, their office culture, and how a typical workday might look for you when you start.

You can enquire about the position – whether it’s a new one; and, if it’s an old position, where did the previous employee move to, etc. You could also ask the interviewer how long they’ve worked there and their favorite thing about their work.

And to end it with a hint of vengeance, ask them where they see the company in the next few years! Be ready with your own job interview questions 😉

Related: 6 Must-Have Skills For Individuals Seeking Remote Jobs In 2021

Want to get more callbacks on applications? It’s time to spruce up your resume.

D’you know what else Roomi does outside of helping its readers figure out interviews and career lives? With our ever-increasing lists of rooms and roommates across the world, we help you find your perfect match! Download the app here and hop on the easiest ride home, ever!

jetpack-related-posts.title: How To Ace Your Job Interview Like A Boss
jetpack-related-posts.author: Team Roomi
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: The thought of a job interview can be quite nerve-wracking and frightening. It starts with "Oh, gosh! I hope they don't see that long career break on my resume." Additionally, "Jeez, I hope my GPA is good enough for them." is often another scary thought. Scores and work history do matter in…

img.alt_text: Guy in red shirt aces job interview

jetpack-related-posts.title: How To Deal With Job Interview Rejection Like A Boss
jetpack-related-posts.author: Team Roomi
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Applying for jobs and doing your best in an interview, and then waiting to hear back is taxing as it is. On top of that, if you have to face rejection, it can be disheartening and demotivating. The good news is, it doesn't have to feel this way. You can…

From sprucing up your resume to making sure you looked your best- you did everything to the best of your abilities. You took the time out to sharpen your professional skills before you even applied for the…

jetpack-related-posts.author: Team Roomi
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: The common perception is that once college is over, you'll be able to put everything that you learned into practice. In reality, it is the skills that you have acquired over time that help you succeed at work. Before a job interview, almost everyone is left wondering if they have…

jetpack-related-posts.author: Team Roomi
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: If you've ever had to sit through a job interview, then you know how important your resume is! It's a way for you to market yourself and promote your career experience. It has your qualifications for a recruiter or hiring manager to clearly see. Your resume is one of the…
